chapter.name: Views
chapter.paragraph: All documents are displayed in ${software} in views. Each view features its own tools, contextual menu commands and hidden keyboard shortcuts, explained in this chapter.

section.name: General
section.paragraph: All documents are displayed in ${software} in views (not to confuse with the different layouts in main windows, also called "views".Each view, e.g. a text or PDF view, has its own tools, contextual menu commands and hidden keyboard shortcuts but is the same in main, document or even "Search" windows. Some views, like the text view, also allow you to edit the document, others like the PDF view, only display the selected document.

subsection.name: Toolbar
subsection.paragraph: ${software} can display documents in separate windows when you double-click them in a main window. Depending on the type of the document, the tools in the toolbar change. Even though not all tools are always present in the default toolbar for a view, you can easily add them by choosing "View > Customize Toolbar...".

subsection.name: Shortcuts & Modifier Keys
subsection.paragraph: Besides shortcuts special to one view or another, many shortcuts work the same for all views (and the same as in most other Mac OS X applications).

section.name: Plain and Rich Texts
section.paragraph: The view for plain and rich text documents is basically a built-in incarnation of TextEdit and you use it in a very similar fashion. Of course, text views support the "Edit > Find > ..."commands and all options of the "Format"menu.

subsection.name: Classify, See Also
subsection.paragraph: Additionally to the standard elements, text views offer access to the concordance,the classify and the see-also functions through buttons in the lower part of the view/edit pane.

subsection.name: The Ruler
subsection.paragraph: For rich text documents, ${software} supports the standard ruler that the TextEdit engine of Mac OS X provides. Show or hide it with "Format > Ruler > Show/Hide Ruler".
The ruler contains the following elements:

list.item: Place tab stops with the mouse, remove them by dragging them away from the ruler. Drag new tab stops (left aligned, centered, right aligned or decimal aligned) from the repository at the right-hand side to their desired positions. Move the left and right margins as well as the indent with the mouse.

Select a predefined text style from the pop-up menu. To define your own styles, choose "Other" to open the Mac OS X standard style editor. In the style editor, navigate back and forth through the styles of your document or the stored favourite styles (use the radio buttons to switch between document and favorite styles). Click "Select" to select all occurences of text with the displayed style in the document, click "Apply" to apply the style to selected text or click "Done" to leave the style editor. To add a style from your document to the favourites, click "Add To Favorites", to remove a favorite, click "Remove From Favorites".
Align the current paragraph (the one with the insertion caret inside) left, centered, justified or right by clicking the according alignment buttons in the ruler.
Choose the desired spacing for the current paragraph from the "Spacing" pop-up menu. Choose "Other" to enter other values than the ones shown.
Make the current paragraph a list item (indented and with a bullet or numbered) by choosing the desired list style from the "Lists" pop-up menu. Choose "Other" to define your own list style.

section.name: Sheets and Records
section.paragraph: Sheetscombine multiple records in a table-like view and are used to create table-like databases within a ${software} database.

Sheets actually appear in the hierarchy list like folders with an expand/collapse triangle in front of them. When you select the sheet itself, it displays as a table (sheet), when you expand it and select a record, it appears as a single record.

The record view displays a single record of a sheet. To display a record separately, either control- or right-click the record in a sheet view and choose "Open..." from the contextual menu, or expand the sheet by clicking the triangle in front of its icon in the hierarchy list and select the record you want to view in a form.
Sheets and records support the "Edit > Find > ..."commands but currently no formattings.
Of course, records can also be grouped within the surrounding sheet like any other document, but will then not be shows as part of the table when the sheet is selected.
section.note: Due to limitation in Mac OS X's Cocoa memory management, sheets are currently limited to 32767 records.

subsection.name: Toolbar
subsection.paragraph: Document windows opened for a sheet or record also feature a tool set specialized for working with sheets and records. Use tools like "New Record", "New Column" or "Columns" to create new records for the sheet, add a column or modify the columns in any way you like. Sheet and record views also can contain tools for paging back and forth through all records of a sheet.

subsection.name: Contextual Menu
subsection.paragraph: The contextual menu for sheets basically lists the same commands that are also available through the main menu.

list.item: Opens a selected record in a sheet in a separate window. Same as double-clicking the record.

section.name: Images and Movies
section.paragraph: ${software} uses Quartz and QuickTime to display images and movies and so makes a very nice image and movie viewer, too.

subsection.name: Toolbar
subsection.paragraph: For images and movies, ${software} provides a set of tools that allows you to zoom the picture to whatever zoom factor you like or to view it in full screen mode. Use "Open Externally" to open the image in an external editor. Movies appear with the standard QuickTime controller.
subsection.note: Editing an image stored internally in the database with an external editor does not modify the image data stored in ${software}!

list.item: Zooms the image so that it appears in its real size, calculated from the actual pixels and the resolution information contained in the image.
Zooms the image so that one image pixel equals one pixel on the screen.
Zooms into and out of the picture.
Zooms the image so that it completely fits into the view/edit pane or the document window.
Zooms the image so that it appears exactly as wide as the view/edit pane or the document window.

section.name: PDFs
section.paragraph: PDF views are pretty similar to image views, but come with some specialized options for viewing PDF documents. Also, PDF views support the "Edit > Find > ..."commands.

subsection.name: Shortcuts & Modifier Keys
subsection.paragraph: In addition to the general shortcuts for paging up and down in a PDF document mentioned in the "General" section,PDF views also offers unique shortcuts.

list.item: Go to first/last page of a PDF document (Mac OS X 10.3.9 only).
Go to next/previous page of a PDF document (Mac OS X 10.3.9 only).

subsection.name: Toolbar
subsection.paragraph: For multi-page images or PDFs, ${software} provides back and forward buttons as well as an page number field at the bottom of the window. Enter any page number and press Return to display that page. For PDFs that contain text, ${software} also provides the same A.I. tools "Words", "Classify" and "See Also"that are also available in plain or rich text views.
